trans-unit.source: Build your first Azure Data Factory pipeline using Visual Studio
trans-unit.target: Build your first Azure Data Factory pipeline using Visual Studio

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial, you will create a sample Azure Data Factory pipeline using Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial, you will create a sample Azure Data Factory pipeline using Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: In this article, you will learn how to use the Visual Studio to create your first pipeline.
trans-unit.target: In this article, you will learn how to use the Visual Studio to create your first pipeline.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial consists of the following steps:
trans-unit.target: This tutorial consists of the following steps:

trans-unit.source: Creating the data factory
trans-unit.target: Creating the data factory

trans-unit.source: Creating the linked services (data stores, computes) and datasets
trans-unit.target: Creating the linked services (data stores, computes) and datasets

trans-unit.source: Creating the pipeline
trans-unit.target: Creating the pipeline

trans-unit.source: This article does not provide a conceptual overview of the Azure Data Factory service.
trans-unit.target: This article does not provide a conceptual overview of the Azure Data Factory service.

trans-unit.source: For a detailed overview of the service, see the <linkText>Introduction to Azure Data Factory</linkText><title></title> article.
trans-unit.target: For a detailed overview of the service, see the <linkText>Introduction to Azure Data Factory</linkText><title></title> article.

trans-unit.source: After logging into the <linkText>Azure Preview Portal</linkText><title></title>, do the following:
trans-unit.target: After logging into the <linkText>Azure Preview Portal</linkText><title></title>, do the following:

trans-unit.source: Click NEW from the bottom-left corner.
trans-unit.target: Click NEW from the bottom-left corner.

trans-unit.source: Click Data analytics in the Create blade.
trans-unit.target: Click Data analytics in the Create blade.

trans-unit.source: Click Data Factory on the Data analytics blade.
trans-unit.target: Click Data Factory on the Data analytics blade.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Create blade</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Create blade</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the New data factory blade, enter DataFactoryMyFirstPipeline for the Name.
trans-unit.target: In the New data factory blade, enter DataFactoryMyFirstPipeline for the Name.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>New data factory blade</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>New data factory blade</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Azure Data Factory names are globally unique.
trans-unit.target: Azure Data Factory names are globally unique.

trans-unit.source: You will need to prefix the name of the data factory with your name, to enable the successful creation of the factory.
trans-unit.target: You will need to prefix the name of the data factory with your name, to enable the successful creation of the factory.

trans-unit.source: If you have not created any resource group, you will need to create a resource group.
trans-unit.target: If you have not created any resource group, you will need to create a resource group.

trans-unit.source: To do this:
trans-unit.target: To do this:

trans-unit.source: Click on RESOURCE GROUP NAME.
trans-unit.target: Click on RESOURCE GROUP NAME.

trans-unit.source: Select Create a new resource group in the Resource group blade.
trans-unit.target: Select Create a new resource group in the Resource group blade.

trans-unit.source: Enter ADF for the Name in the Create resource group blade.
trans-unit.target: Enter ADF for the Name in the Create resource group blade.

trans-unit.source: Click OK.
trans-unit.target: Click OK.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Create resource group</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Create resource group</linkText>

trans-unit.source: After you have selected the resource group, verify that you are using the correct subscription where you want the data factory to be created.
trans-unit.target: After you have selected the resource group, verify that you are using the correct subscription where you want the data factory to be created.

trans-unit.source: Click Create on the New data factory blade.
trans-unit.target: Click Create on the New data factory blade.

trans-unit.source: You will see the data factory being created in the Startboard of the Azure Preview Portal as follows:
trans-unit.target: You will see the data factory being created in the Startboard of the Azure Preview Portal as follows:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Creating data factory status</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Creating data factory status</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Congratulations!
trans-unit.target: Congratulations!

trans-unit.source: You have successfully created your first data factory.
trans-unit.target: You have successfully created your first data factory.

trans-unit.source: After the data factory has been created successfully, you will see the data factory page, which shows you the contents of the data factory.
trans-unit.target: After the data factory has been created successfully, you will see the data factory page, which shows you the contents of the data factory.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Data Factory blade</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Data Factory blade</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the subsequent steps, you will learn how to create the linked services, datasets and pipeline that you will use in this tutorial.
trans-unit.target: In the subsequent steps, you will learn how to create the linked services, datasets and pipeline that you will use in this tutorial.

trans-unit.source: You must have the following installed on your computer:
trans-unit.target: You must have the following installed on your computer:

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio 2013
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio 2013

trans-unit.source: Download Azure SDK for Visual Studio 2013.
trans-unit.target: Download Azure SDK for Visual Studio 2013.

trans-unit.source: Navigate to Azure Download Page and click VS 2013 install in the .NET section.
trans-unit.target: Navigate to Azure Download Page and click VS 2013 install in the .NET section.

trans-unit.source: Launch Visual Studio 2013.
trans-unit.target: Launch Visual Studio 2013.

trans-unit.source: Click File, point to New, and click Project.
trans-unit.target: Click File, point to New, and click Project.

trans-unit.source: You should see the New Project dialog box.
trans-unit.target: You should see the New Project dialog box.

trans-unit.source: In the New Project dialog, select the DataFactory template, and click Empty Data Factory Project.
trans-unit.target: In the New Project dialog, select the DataFactory template, and click Empty Data Factory Project.

trans-unit.source: If you don't see the DataFactory template, close Visual Studio, install Azure SDK for Visual Studio 2013, and reopen Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: If you don't see the DataFactory template, close Visual Studio, install Azure SDK for Visual Studio 2013, and reopen Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>New project dialog box</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>New project dialog box</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Enter a name for the project, location, and a name for the solution, and click OK.
trans-unit.target: Enter a name for the project, location, and a name for the solution, and click OK.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Solution Explorer</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Solution Explorer</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In this step, you will link your Azure Storage account and an on-demand Azure HDInsight cluster to your data factory and then crate a dataset to represent the output data from Hive processing.
trans-unit.target: In this step, you will link your Azure Storage account and an on-demand Azure HDInsight cluster to your data factory and then crate a dataset to represent the output data from Hive processing.

trans-unit.source: Right-click Linked Services in the solution explorer, point to Add, and click New Item.
trans-unit.target: Right-click Linked Services in the solution explorer, point to Add, and click New Item.

trans-unit.source: In the Add New Item dialog box, select Azure Storage Linked Service from the list, and click Add.
trans-unit.target: In the Add New Item dialog box, select Azure Storage Linked Service from the list, and click Add.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>New Linked Service</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>New Linked Service</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Replace accountname and accountkey with the name of your Azure storage account and its key.
trans-unit.target: Replace accountname and accountkey with the name of your Azure storage account and its key.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Azure Storage Linked Service</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Azure Storage Linked Service</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Save the AzureStorageLinkedService1.json file.
trans-unit.target: Save the AzureStorageLinkedService1.json file.

trans-unit.source: Now, you will create a linked service for an on-demand HDInsight cluster that will be used to run the Hive script.
trans-unit.target: Now, you will create a linked service for an on-demand HDInsight cluster that will be used to run the Hive script.

trans-unit.source: In the Solution Explorer, right-click Linked Services, point to Add, and click New Item.
trans-unit.target: In the Solution Explorer, right-click Linked Services, point to Add, and click New Item.

trans-unit.source: Select HDInsight On Demand Linked Service, and click Add.
trans-unit.target: Select HDInsight On Demand Linked Service, and click Add.

trans-unit.source: Replace the JSON with the following:
trans-unit.target: Replace the JSON with the following:

trans-unit.source: The following table provides descriptions for the JSON properties used in the snippet:
trans-unit.target: The following table provides descriptions for the JSON properties used in the snippet:

trans-unit.source: Property | Description -------- | ----------- Version | This specifies that the version of the HDInsight created to be 3.1.
trans-unit.target: Property | Description -------- | ----------- Version | This specifies that the version of the HDInsight created to be 3.1.

trans-unit.source: ClusterSize | This creates a one node HDInsight cluster.
trans-unit.target: ClusterSize | This creates a one node HDInsight cluster.

trans-unit.source: TimeToLive | This specifies that the idle time for the HDInsight cluster, before it is deleted.
trans-unit.target: TimeToLive | This specifies that the idle time for the HDInsight cluster, before it is deleted.

trans-unit.source: JobsContainer | This specifies the name of the job container that will be created to store the logs that are generated by HDInsight linkedServiceName | This specifies the storage account that will be used to store the logs that are generated by HDInsight
trans-unit.target: JobsContainer | This specifies the name of the job container that will be created to store the logs that are generated by HDInsight linkedServiceName | This specifies the storage account that will be used to store the logs that are generated by HDInsight

trans-unit.source: Save the HDInsightOnDemandLinkedService1.json file.
trans-unit.target: Save the HDInsightOnDemandLinkedService1.json file.

trans-unit.source: Now, you will create the output dataset to represent the data stored in the Azure Blob storage.
trans-unit.target: Now, you will create the output dataset to represent the data stored in the Azure Blob storage.

trans-unit.source: In the Solution Explorer, right-click point to Add, and click New Item.
trans-unit.target: In the Solution Explorer, right-click point to Add, and click New Item.

trans-unit.source: Select Azure Blob from the list, and click Add.
trans-unit.target: Select Azure Blob from the list, and click Add.

trans-unit.source: Replace the JSON in the editor with the following: In the JSON snippet, you are creating a dataset called AzureBlobOutput, and specifying the structure of the data that will be produced by the Hive script.
trans-unit.target: Replace the JSON in the editor with the following: In the JSON snippet, you are creating a dataset called AzureBlobOutput, and specifying the structure of the data that will be produced by the Hive script.

trans-unit.source: In addition, you specify that the results are stored in the blob container called data and the folder called partitioneddata.
trans-unit.target: In addition, you specify that the results are stored in the blob container called data and the folder called partitioneddata.

trans-unit.source: The availability section specifies that the output dataset is produced on a monthly basis.
trans-unit.target: The availability section specifies that the output dataset is produced on a monthly basis.

trans-unit.source: Save the AzureBlobLocation1.json file.
trans-unit.target: Save the AzureBlobLocation1.json file.

trans-unit.source: In this step, you will create your first pipeline.
trans-unit.target: In this step, you will create your first pipeline.

trans-unit.source: In the Solution Explorer, right-click Pipelines, point to Add, and click New Item.
trans-unit.target: In the Solution Explorer, right-click Pipelines, point to Add, and click New Item.

trans-unit.source: Select Hive Transformation Pipeline from the list, and click Add.
trans-unit.target: Select Hive Transformation Pipeline from the list, and click Add.

trans-unit.source: Replace the JSON with the following snippet and replace storageaccountname with the name of your storage account.
trans-unit.target: Replace the JSON with the following snippet and replace storageaccountname with the name of your storage account.

trans-unit.source: In the JSON snippet, you are creating a pipeline that consists of a single activity that uses Hive to process Data on an HDInsight cluster.
trans-unit.target: In the JSON snippet, you are creating a pipeline that consists of a single activity that uses Hive to process Data on an HDInsight cluster.

trans-unit.source: The Hive script file, partitionweblogs.hql, is stored in the Azure storage account (specified by the scriptLinkedService, called AzureStorageLinkedService1), and in a container called script.
trans-unit.target: The Hive script file, partitionweblogs.hql, is stored in the Azure storage account (specified by the scriptLinkedService, called AzureStorageLinkedService1), and in a container called script.

trans-unit.source: The extendedProperties section is used to specify the runtime settings that will be passed to the hive script as Hive configuration values (e.g ${hiveconf:PartitionedData}).
trans-unit.target: The extendedProperties section is used to specify the runtime settings that will be passed to the hive script as Hive configuration values (e.g ${hiveconf:PartitionedData}).

trans-unit.source: The start and end properties of the pipeline specifies the active period of the pipeline.
trans-unit.target: The start and end properties of the pipeline specifies the active period of the pipeline.

trans-unit.source: In the activity JSON, you specify that the Hive script runs on the compute specified by the linked service – HDInsightOnDemandLinkedService.
trans-unit.target: In the activity JSON, you specify that the Hive script runs on the compute specified by the linked service – HDInsightOnDemandLinkedService.

trans-unit.source: Save the HiveActivity1.json file.
trans-unit.target: Save the HiveActivity1.json file.

trans-unit.source: Right-click Dependencies in the Solution Explorer window, point to Add, and click Existing Item.
trans-unit.target: Right-click Dependencies in the Solution Explorer window, point to Add, and click Existing Item.

trans-unit.source: Navigate to the C:\ADFGettingStarted and select partitionweblogs.hql file, and click Add.
trans-unit.target: Navigate to the C:\ADFGettingStarted and select partitionweblogs.hql file, and click Add.

trans-unit.source: When you publish the solution in the next step, the HQL file is uploaded to the scripts container in your blob storage.
trans-unit.target: When you publish the solution in the next step, the HQL file is uploaded to the scripts container in your blob storage.

trans-unit.source: In the toolbar area, right-click and select Data Factory to enable the Data Factory toolbar if it is not already enabled.
trans-unit.target: In the toolbar area, right-click and select Data Factory to enable the Data Factory toolbar if it is not already enabled.

trans-unit.source: In the Data Factory toolbar, click the drop-down box to see all the data factories in your Azure subscription.
trans-unit.target: In the Data Factory toolbar, click the drop-down box to see all the data factories in your Azure subscription.

trans-unit.source: If you see the Sign-in to Visual Studio dialog box:
trans-unit.target: If you see the Sign-in to Visual Studio dialog box:

trans-unit.source: Enter the email account associated with the Azure subscription in which you want to create the data factory, enter Password, and click Sign-in.
trans-unit.target: Enter the email account associated with the Azure subscription in which you want to create the data factory, enter Password, and click Sign-in.

trans-unit.source: Once the sign-in is successful, you should see all the data factories in the Azure subscription.
trans-unit.target: Once the sign-in is successful, you should see all the data factories in the Azure subscription.

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial, you will create a new data facotry.
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial, you will create a new data facotry.

trans-unit.source: In the drop-down list, select DataFactoryMyFirstPipeline, and click Publish button to deploy/publish the linked services, datasets, and the pipeline.
trans-unit.target: In the drop-down list, select DataFactoryMyFirstPipeline, and click Publish button to deploy/publish the linked services, datasets, and the pipeline.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Publish button</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Publish button</linkText>

trans-unit.source: You should see the status of publishing in the Data Factory Task List window that is shown in the picture above.
trans-unit.target: You should see the status of publishing in the Data Factory Task List window that is shown in the picture above.

trans-unit.source: Confirm that publishing has succeeded.
trans-unit.target: Confirm that publishing has succeeded.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, click View on the menu, and click Server Explorer.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, click View on the menu, and click Server Explorer.

trans-unit.source: In the Server Explorer window, expand Azure and expand Data Factory.
trans-unit.target: In the Server Explorer window, expand Azure and expand Data Factory.

trans-unit.source: If you see Sign in to Visual Studio, enter the account associated with your Azure subscription and click Continue.
trans-unit.target: If you see Sign in to Visual Studio, enter the account associated with your Azure subscription and click Continue.

trans-unit.source: Enter password, and click Sign in.
trans-unit.target: Enter password, and click Sign in.

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio tries to get information about all Azure data factories in your subscription.
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio tries to get information about all Azure data factories in your subscription.

trans-unit.source: You will see the status of this operation in the Data Factory Task List window.
trans-unit.target: You will see the status of this operation in the Data Factory Task List window.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Server Explorer</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Server Explorer</linkText>

trans-unit.source: You can right-click on a data factory, and select Export Data Factory to New Project to create a Visual Studio project based on an existing data factory.
trans-unit.target: You can right-click on a data factory, and select Export Data Factory to New Project to create a Visual Studio project based on an existing data factory.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Export data factory</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Export data factory</linkText>

trans-unit.source: To update Azure Data Factory tools for Visual Studio, do the following:
trans-unit.target: To update Azure Data Factory tools for Visual Studio, do the following:

trans-unit.source: Click Tools on the menu and select Extensions and Updates.
trans-unit.target: Click Tools on the menu and select Extensions and Updates.

trans-unit.source: Select Updates in the left pane and then select Visual Studio Gallery.
trans-unit.target: Select Updates in the left pane and then select Visual Studio Gallery.

trans-unit.source: Select Azure Data Factory tools for Visual Studio and click Update.
trans-unit.target: Select Azure Data Factory tools for Visual Studio and click Update.

trans-unit.source: If you do not see this entry, you already have the latest version of the tools.
trans-unit.target: If you do not see this entry, you already have the latest version of the tools.

trans-unit.source: See <linkText>Monitor datasets and pipeline</linkText><title></title> for instructions on how to use the Azure Preview Portal to monitor the pipeline and datasets you have created in this tutorial.
trans-unit.target: See <linkText>Monitor datasets and pipeline</linkText><title></title> for instructions on how to use the Azure Preview Portal to monitor the pipeline and datasets you have created in this tutorial.

trans-unit.source: In this article, you have created a pipeline with a transformation activity (HDInsight Activity) that runs a Hive script on an on-demand HDInsight cluster.
trans-unit.target: In this article, you have created a pipeline with a transformation activity (HDInsight Activity) that runs a Hive script on an on-demand HDInsight cluster.

trans-unit.source: To see how to use a Copy Activity to copy data from an Azure Blob to Azure SQL, see <linkText>Tutorial: Copy data from an Azure blob to Azure SQL</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: To see how to use a Copy Activity to copy data from an Azure Blob to Azure SQL, see <linkText>Tutorial: Copy data from an Azure blob to Azure SQL</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: We would really appreciate your feedback on this article.
trans-unit.target: We would really appreciate your feedback on this article.

trans-unit.source: Please take a few minutes to submit your feedback via <linkText>email</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: Please take a few minutes to submit your feedback via <linkText>email</linkText><title></title>.
